nodes.title: Page 34
nodes.summary:
Page 34 of the PDF "26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf" discusses the absence of evidence on trade usage of the impugned mark in India by the appellant. Mr. Sibal, representing Respondent 1, argues that:

* No evidence of trade usage has been provided by the appellant.
* Judgments relied upon by Mr. Anand were rendered in infringement claims or relative grounds for refusal of registration, not absolute grounds under Section 9.
* As the application was on a "proposed to be used" basis, prior usage became irrelevant.

Moreover, Mr. Sibal disputes the allegation of fabrication of an invoice by Respondent 2, pointing out that:

* The issue is raised for the first time in the appeal and not in the lower court proceedings.
* The use of the ₹ symbol was due to software technical issues.
* Apart from the disputed invoice, several other invoices were filed to evidence sales using the impugned mark.

nodes.title: Page 35
nodes.summary:
Based on page 35 of the PDF "26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf", here is a summary of the relevant content:

**Arguments:**

* Mr. Sibal submits that registration of the mark is mandatory, as it does not fall under Section 9 or Section 11 of the Trade Marks Act.
* Mr. Anand argues in rejoinder that the European Union Intellectual Property Office (EUIPO) order dated April 7, 2022, does not apply to this case due to differences in Indian and EU laws regarding confusion and deception.

**Key points:**

* The onus of proof under Indian law is different from EU law.
* The EUIPO order found that "potential deception unconnected to the quality of the goods/services provided under the mark" was not grounds for rejection.
* The judge notes the distinction in the marks used in the present case (cross logo) and the EUIPO case (Swiss Military By PSM).

**Sources:**

* PDF source: "26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf"
* Relevant sections of Indian law: Section 9, Section 11 of the Trade Marks Act
* EU law: European Union Intellectual Property Office (EUIPO) order dated April 7, 2022

* The case revolves around Applicant Armasuisse's opposition to Respondent 1's trademark registration in India.
* Mr. Anand, representing Applicant Armasuisse, argues that the use of a similar mark by Respondent 1 could lead to consumer deception or confusion (Section 9(2)(a)6).
* He relies on judgments like Amritdhara Pharmacy and Louis Vitton Malletier to support this argument.
* Mr. Anand submits that an unwary consumer in India may associate the goods bearing the impugned mark with Switzerland, given its international reputation.
* The principle of territoriality is claimed not to apply in this case since Respondent 1 has taken steps to create a connection between the mark and Switzerland (e.g., seeking a license from Armasuisse).
* Key legal provisions mentioned include Section 9(2)(a)6, Section 57(8)19 of the Evidence Act, and Toyota Jidosha Kabushiki Kaisa.

Note: The provided PDF has been scanned and appears to be digitally signed on January 4, 2023.

nodes.title: Page 38
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 38 from the PDF file Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf:

The Court emphasizes the importance of guarding the right to registration of a mark as a trade mark. Any provision that curtails this right must be strictly construed, and the right cannot be denied based on fanciful apprehensions.

At the same time, the Court must also consider statutory provisions in Sections 9 and 11 of the Trade Marks Act, which set out prohibitions against registration. These provisions serve to counter-balance the rights of industry and consumer public by preventing confusion or deception of consumers.

The Court is required to strike a delicate balance between these competing considerations when arriving at its conclusion. This balance will determine whether the impugned mark is considered a "false trade description" under Sections 2(1)(i)(I) and 2(1)(za)2.

(Source: Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf, page 38, Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000019)
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000019 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 & cont. matter 
Page 38 of 79 
 
 
reputation in the market, but also restricts the rights and privileges of 
all others who, even unintentionally, may be using a confusingly 
similar mark.  The right to registration must, therefore, be sedulously 
guarded.  Any provision which abrogates, or even curtails, the right 
to registration of a mark as a trade mark has, therefore, to be strictly 
construed.  The right of registration to a mark cannot be denied on 
fanciful apprehensions.   
 
66. 
On the flip side, the Court is also required to be mindful of the 
proscriptions statutorily engrafted in Sections 9 and 11 of the Trade 
Marks Act.  Where a mark is statutorily non-registerable under the 
said provisions, the Court cannot, by interpretative calisthenics, 
compel the Registrar to register it.  The prohibitions against 
registration, as contained in Sections 9 and 11, have a public purpose 
to serve.  They serve to counter-balance the rights of the industry and 
the rights of the consumer public.   Confusion or deception of the 
consumer is completely impermissible in law.  Howsoever innocent 
the user of the confusing mark may be, no equities lie in his favour.  
These considerations, too, therefore, have to guide the approach of 
the Court. 
 
67. 
The Court is, therefore, required to strike, in such cases, a 
delicate balance while arriving at its conclusion. 
 
I. 
Is the impugned mark a ―false trade description‖?  If so, is it 
non-registerable? 
 
68. 
Examination of these aspects would decide the submissions of 
both sides with respect to Sections 2(1)(i)(I) and 2(1)(za)2 as well as

nodes.summary:
Page 39 from the PDF "26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf" summarizes a judgment related to trademark registration. Key points:

* Section 9(2)(a)6 of the Trade Marks Act is relevant.
* The impugned order does not address the issues of registerability.

Arguments:

* Mr. Anand argues that the impugned mark is non-registerable as it amounts to a "false trade description".
* Mr. Sibal disagrees, stating that even if it were, it doesn't become non-registerable per se due to consequences in Sections 1034 and 10422 of the Trade Marks Act.

Definitions:

* Section 2(1)(i) defines "false trade description" as a description that is untrue or misleading.
* Section 2(1)(za)(iv) defines "trade description" as any statement indicating origin, country, time, production, etc.

The matter revolves around the registration of a trademark which might be considered a "false trade description". The court will decide on its registerability.

nodes.title: Page 40
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 40 from the provided PDF (Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf):

**Context:** The High Court of Delhi at New Delhi, C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022.

**Text:**

The court discusses Section 9(2)(a) of the Trademarks Act, which prohibits registration of a mark if it deceives the public or causes confusion. It defines a "false trade description" as one that is untrue or misleading in a material respect regarding the goods to which it applies. The court concludes that:

* A trade mark that contains an untrue or misleading statement about the country of manufacture of goods would be considered a "false trade description".
* Such a mark would deceive the public and cause confusion, rendering it ineligible for registration under Section 9(2)(a).
* The impugned mark may also fall under this category.

**Key points:**

* Section 9(2)(a) prohibits registration of marks that deceive or confuse.
* A "false trade description" is one that is untrue or misleading regarding goods to which it applies.
* An untrue statement about country of manufacture renders a mark ineligible for registration.

material respect regarding the goods to which is applied is a false 
trade description.  The country of manufacture of goods is certainly a 
―material respect‖, within the meaning of Section 2(1)(i)(I).  If a 
trade mark is untrue or misleading regarding the country of origin of 
the goods on which it is used, there is no reason to believe that it

One may, in this context, borrow the following well-known aphorism 
of Lindley, LJ in Slazenger & Sons v. Feltham & Co.38:

should we be astute to say that he cannot succeed in doing that 
which he is straining every nerve to do?‖ 
 
Any description, statement or other indication, direct or indirect, as to 
the country of manufacture or production of goods, contained in the 
trade mark affixed on the goods would, therefore, be a ―false trade 
description‖ and, inasmuch as the mark would be of a nature which 
would deceive the public or cause confusion, would also be ineligible 
for registration under Section 9(2)(a).

nodes.title: Page 41
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 41 from the PDF:

**Legal Proceedings:** 
The High Court of Delhi at New Delhi in C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 and cont. matter.

**Key Point:** 
The court examines Section 2(1)(za)(iv) of the Trade Marks Act to determine when a description or indication in a trade mark is considered a "trade description".

**Quotes from the Judgment:**

* "Any description, statement, or other indication as to the place or country where the goods were made or produced... would be a ―trade description‖ within the meaning of Section 2(1)(za)"
* "Much turns, in my view, on the words ―direct or indirect‖. The legislature, classically, does not engage in superfluity or tautology."

**Definitions and Clarifications:** 
"Indirect" is defined as describing something associated with but not immediately connected to something else.

References: Advanced Law Lexicon by P. Ramanatha Aiyar and Supreme Court cases Dilbagh Rai Jerry v. U.O.I, C.I.T. v. R.M. Aiyar, and Umed v. Raj Singh.

**Source:** 26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf

C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 & cont. matter 
Page 41 of 79 
 
 
the meaning of Section 2(1)(za)(iv) of the Trade Marks Act? 
 
76. 
Any description, statement, or other indication as to the place 
or country where the goods were made or produced, as contained in a 
trade mark, would be a ―trade description‖ within the meaning of 
Section 2(1)(za).  The description may be direct or indirect.  The 
definition would also encompass any description which is likely to be 
misunderstood or mistaken for an indication regarding the place or 
country where the goods are made or produced.   
 
77. 
Much turns, in my view, on the words ―direct or indirect‖.  The 
legislature, classically, does not engage in superfluity or tautology39.  
The words ―direct or indirect‖ have, therefore, to be regarded as 
deliberately included.  They connote, in the context of Section 
2(1)(za)(iv), not merely a direct, but also an indirect description, 
statement or other indication, in the trade mark, regarding the place 
or country or manufacture or production of the goods.  If, therefore, 
the trade mark even indirectly indicates the country of manufacture 
of the goods, it is a ―trade description‖ within the meaning of Section 
2(1)(za)(iv). 
 
78. 
―Indirect‖ is defined, in P. Ramanatha Aiyar‘s Advanced Law 
Lexicon, as ―describing something that is associated with, but not 
immediately connected to, something else; something at one 
remove‖.  The expression ―direct or indirect‖, as used in Section 
2(1)(za), has to be read in conjunction with the inclusive part of the 
definition which, as used in the provision, is essentially clarificatory

Raj Singh, (1975) 1 SCC 76

Based on page 42 of the PDF "26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf", here is a summary of the key points:

**Legal Issues:**

* The court discusses the definition of "trade description" under Section 2(1)(za) and Clause (c), which refers to descriptions that are likely to be misunderstood or mistaken for the country of manufacture.
* If the mark suggests a country of origin that is not true, it may be considered a false trade description under Section 2(1)(i)(I).
* The words "likely to be misunderstood" and "untrue or misleading" read together apply the decision in National Sewing Thread Co. Ltd v. James Chadwick & Bros (1953).

**Key Quotes:**

* Clause (c) of Section 2(1)(za): any description which is likely to be misunderstood or mistaken for the country of manufacture or production.
* Section 2(1)(i)(I): untrue or misleading in a material respect.

nodes.title: Page 43
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 43 from the PDF:

The decision states that in determining whether a trade mark is likely to deceive or cause confusion, one must consider how an "average man" with ordinary intelligence would react to the mark. To make this determination, one must consider what impression the mark creates and any associations it may form with existing marks.

This passage was approved by Nandhini Deluxe v. Karnataka Co-operative Milk Producers Federation Ltd (2018) 9 SCC 183. Further, a court should factor in that the average consumer:

* Takes a global view of the mark as a whole
* Does not analyze its various details
* Recognizes distinctive and dominant components
* May have an imperfect picture or recollection of the marks

The passage was from the decision of the High Court of England and Wales in Compass Publishing B.V. v. Compass Logistics Ltd (2004) RPC 41.

Source: Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr, Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000019, PDF source.

particular trade mark is likely to deceive or cause confusion that 
duty is not discharged by arriving at the result by merely 
comparing it with the trade mark which is already registered and 
whose proprietor is offering opposition to the registration of the 
mark. The real question to decide in such cases is to see as to how 
a purchaser, who must be looked upon as an average man of 
ordinary intelligence, would react to a particular trade mark, what 
association he would form by looking at the trade mark, and in 
what respect he would connect the trade mark with the goods 
which he would be purchasing.‖

Page 44 of PDF: "Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr" (2023/DHC/000019) 

Key points:

* The court considers the likelihood of confusion when comparing two trade marks, highlighting that if goods come from the same or economically linked undertakings, there is a likelihood of confusion.
* Mr. Sibal argues that Section 9(2)(a) of the Trade Marks Act only applies if the impugned mark deceives the public or causes confusion.
* The court agrees with Mr. Sibal, stating that Section 9(2)(a) does not allow it to travel outside the mark itself; the mark's nature must deceive or cause confusion.

Relevant section (Section 9 of Trade Marks Act):

* Sub-section (1): Defines "trade description" and refers to a person being misled.
* Sub-section (2)(a) deals with marks that deceive or cause confusion.
* The court mentions Amritdhara Pharmacy (15) and Mahendra & Mahendra Paper Mills Ltd v. Mahindra & Mahendra Ltd (46) regarding the class of consumers who may be purchasing the goods.

nodes.title: Page 45
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 45 from the PDF "26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf":

The court examines whether the impugned mark "Swiss Military" with a red-and-white cross can be registered as a trade mark.

The court holds that:

* The use of "German-made" is irrelevant to the case at hand (Slazenger principle)
* Any customer of average intelligence would know that the red-and-white cross is an indicia of the Swiss confederation
* The impugned mark, by its very nature, has the potential to deceive or cause confusion that the goods are made in Switzerland
* The virtues of the military establishment are irrelevant to the controversy
* Section 9(2)(a) of the Trade Marks Act does not expound on the nature of deception or confusion, and therefore an absolute proscription against registration applies

Source: "26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf" (PDF source).

Note that this summary is under 200 words and focuses on legal facts, proceedings, arguments, decisions, dates, names, and amounts as requested.

regard the mark as indicating that the goods are of Swiss origin.  The

the country where the goods, bearing the mark, are manufactured or 
produced.  The Slazenger38 principle would also directly apply in such

nodes.title: Page 46
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 46 from the PDF "26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf":

On page 46, the court discusses Section 9(2)(a) of the Trademarks Act, which states that a mark should not be registered if it deceives or confuses the average consumer into mistaking the goods as being from Switzerland when they are actually of Chinese origin.

The court notes that whether the average consumer would regard the goods as made by the Swiss army is irrelevant. What matters is whether the consumer would be deceived or confused into believing the goods were manufactured in Switzerland, not by the Swiss army.

To distinguish between "deception" and "confusion", the court cites Lord Denning's comments from Parker-Knoll Ltd v. Knoll International Ltd (1962 RPC 265): deception involves telling a lie or making a false representation, whereas confusion can occur even when truth is told if the consumer lacks knowledge or ability to distinguish between truths.

PDF source: "26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf"
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000019

Page 46 of 79 
 
 
2(1)(za), if the impugned mark deceives, or confuses, the average 
consumer into mistaking the goods to be manufactured or produced in 
Switzerland, i.e., of Swiss origin, it is immediately hit by Section 
9(2)(a), as the goods are, admittedly, not of Swiss, but of Chinese, 
origin.  Whether the average consumer would regard the goods as 
made or manufactured by the Swiss army, or the Swiss military 
establishment is, therefore, irrelevant.  What has to be seen is whether 
the average consumer – with the intellectual abilities attributed to him 
by Compass Publishing43 – would be deceived, or confused, into 
believing the goods to have been manufactured or produced in 
Switzerland, not manufactured or produced by the Swiss army.   
 
85. 
―Deception‖ and ―confusion‖ are different concepts, and, on the 
distinction between the two, the following exordium of Lord Denning 
in Parker-Knoll Ltd v. Knoll International Ltd47 (cited, with approval 
by the Supreme Court, in, inter alia, F. Hoffmann-La Roche & Co. v. 
Geoffrey Manner & Co. Pvt Ltd48) has become locus classicus: 
―Secondly, 'to deceive' is one thing. To 'cause confusion' is 
another. The difference is this: When you deceive a man, you tell 
him a lie. You make a false representation to him and thereby 
cause him to believe a thing to be true which is false. You may not 
do it knowingly, or intentionally, but still you do it, and so you 
deceive him. But you may cause confusion without telling him a 
lie at all, and without making any false representation to him. You 
may indeed tell him the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the 
truth, but still you may cause confusion in his mind, not by any 
fault of yours, but because he has not the knowledge or ability to 
distinguish it from the other pieces of truth known to him or 
because he may not even take the trouble to do so.‖ 
 
I may usefully profit from the following clear understanding of the 
difference between ―confusion‖ and ―deception‖, vis-à-vis use of a

nodes.title: Page 47
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 47 from the PDF "26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf":

**Case:** C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 & cont. matter
**Court:** High Court of Delhi at New Delhi
**Reference to another judgment:** Shree Nath Heritage Liquor

**Key points:**

1. If a consumer is unsure whether there's a connection between two marks, it's deemed confusion.
2. A person is confused when they don't know which mark belongs to whom (A or B).
3. Deception occurs when the consumer believes one mark is another (A is B or B is A).

**Argument from Appellant:**

1. The impugned mark uses the Swiss insignia and words "SWISS MILITARY", likely confusing consumers into believing the goods were manufactured in Switzerland.
2. This renders the mark ineligible for registration under Section 2(1)(i)(I) and Section 9(2)(a) of the Trade Marks Act.

Source: Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000019, C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 & cont. matter, Page 47 of 79, from PDF "26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf".

then it's a step before confusion. If on the other hand, the consumer

product, this is then deception.‖ 
 
Though this explanation is in the context of confusion between the 
marks used by a ―junior‖ and a ―senior‖ user, it would hold equally 
true on the aspect of distinction between confusion and deception in 
general.  A person is confused when he does not know which is A and 
which is B.  He is deceived when he is made to believe A to be B or B 
to be A.  That, plainly, is the distinction. 
 
86. 
Once this distinction is also borne in mind, the conclusion is 
obvious.  The impugned mark, which not only uses the 
 Swiss 
insignia, but also the words ―SWISS MILITARY‖ below it, would 
clearly, at the very least, confuse the consumer of average intelligence 
into assuming the goods to have been manufactured or produced in 
Switzerland.  The mark would, thereby, be a ―false trade description‖ 
and be ineligible to registration within the meaning of Section 
2(1)(i)(I) as well as be rendered ineligible to registration under 
Section 9(2)(a) of the Trade Marks Act. 
 
87. 
The observations, in the impugned order, that the impugned 
mark has rounded corners, and that the arms of the cross as used in it 
do not appear to be of the same length, fail to commend acceptance.  
To a person who views the mark as affixed on goods, these 
distinctions pale into significance. Mr. Sibal, in his arguments, 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:04.01.2023
15:28:31
Signature Not Verified

nodes.title: Page 48
nodes.summary:
Based on page 48 of the PDF "26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf", here's a summary of the key points:

**Background**: The court is reviewing an appeal in the case of Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr, C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022.

**Argument**: Mr. Pravin Anand, representing Appellant Armasuisse, argued that Respondent 2 (Trade Mark Registry) erred in not considering facts about the impugned mark's actual use and registration history. 

**Key Points**:

* The impugned mark is registered for various classes of goods, including key chains, pens, school bags, and leather products.
* Respondent 2 has acknowledged using the same mark for a backpack (photo in para 24).
* The mark's shape, as actually used, doesn't show apparent differences in arm lengths or round edges, despite claims to the contrary.
* Mr. Sibal acknowledges that these registrations include marks in red-and-white color combination.

**Court Observations**: Unfortunately, the learned Deputy Registrar failed to notice these facts, leading to an error in their decision.

Source: PDF "26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf"

backpack, the photograph of which is to be found in para 24 supra.  
The mark, as actually used, does not make apparent, to the person 
viewing the mark, any difference in the lengths of the arms of the 
white cross, or any roundness in the edges of the corners of the

nodes.title: Page 49
nodes.summary:
Here is the summary:

**Case:** Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr (2023/DHC/000019)
**PDF Source:** 26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf

**Page 49:**

* The Deputy Registrar observed that even if the impugned trademark is registered in black and white, it would be deemed to be registered for all colors under Section 10 of the Trade Marks Act.
* However, he distinguished between "all colors" and "every possible color scheme/combination of colors", finding this distinction too facile to have legal merit.
* The issue arises when considering substitution of colors in a registered trademark, including the case at hand where only one additional color (red) is involved.
* The Deputy Registrar concluded that once the mark stands registered for all colors, it also stands registered for use with a red background instead of the original black.

**Key dates and names:**

* Reserved on 14th December 2022
* Pronounced on 4th January 2023
* Deputy Registrar (name not specified)
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000019 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 & cont. matter 
Page 49 of 79 
 
 
  
88. 
It is important, at this point, to advert to the observations of the 
learned Deputy Registrar on Section 10(2) of the Trade Marks Act, 
contained in para 42 of the impugned order.  At the cost of repetition, 
they may once again be reproduced thus: 
―The Ld. Counsel for the opponent has argued that in case the 
impugned trademarks is registered in black and white, as per 
section 10 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, it would be deemed to be 
registered for all colors, therefore, color of the impugned 
trademark is not of much significance for the purpose of 
comparison of the marks. I do agree with the Ld. Counsel for the 
opponent to the extent he says that as per section 10, a mark if 
registered in black and white colour would be deemed to be 
registered for all colors, however, it doesn’t naturally follow from 
this that the mark would be deemed to be registered in every 
possible color scheme/combination of colors including the color 
scheme/combination of colors of the Swiss emblem.‖ 
(Emphasis supplied) 
 
To my mind, the italicized words in the afore-extracted passage from 
the impugned order return two mutually contradictory findings.  In the 
first breath, the learned Deputy Registrar agrees that the registration 
of the impugned mark without limitation of colour would deem it to 
be registered for all colours.  In the very same breath, he goes on to 
observe that it would not naturally follow that the mark would be 
deemed to be registered in every possible colour scheme/combination 
of colours.  This distinction, between ―all colours‖ and ―every 
possible colour scheme/combination of colours‖, to my mind, is too 
facile to pass legal muster.  In any event, in the present case, there is 
only one colour involved, apart from black and white, which is red.  
Once, therefore, the 
 mark stood registered for all colours, it also 
stands registered for use by substituting the black with a red 
background.  
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI

The page content from Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr (2023/DHC/000019) PDF focuses on the court's analysis of the disputed trademark.

**Key points:**

* The respondent's use of the "SWISS MILITARY" logo below a mark resembling the Swiss insignia would dispel any distinctiveness from the original insignia.

* The court observes that the impugned order's finding on the assumption of origin is unsupported and unsustainable.

**Relevant details:**

 mark, 
with slightly rounded corners, were to be distinguishable from the

 mark, even if its corners were not as pointed, 
when used with the ‗SWISS MILITARY‘ logo immediately below it, 
is bound, by its very nature, to create confusion in the mind of the

nodes.title: Page 51
nodes.summary:
**Summary of Page 51 from Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr (2023/DHC/000019)**

The court is examining a trade mark dispute between Armasuisse (Appellant) and Respondents 1 and 2. On page 51, the judge discusses that:

* The Appellant has applied for registration of device marks and word marks related to goods in various classes.
* There is no evidence to support the Deputy Registrar's finding that the Appellant would not engage in manufacturing or trading activities.
* The Slazenger principle (Slazenger v. Mobil Oil, 1980) may be applicable by analogy in this case, given the Respondent's use of Swiss insignia and word marks such as "SWISS MILITARY".
* The use of the red-and-white cross-and-square Swiss insignia appears to be an attempt to confuse consumers into associating the goods with the Swiss military establishment.
* The court should not presume that the attempt to confuse would not be successful, and minor differences between the marks (e.g., curved corners) are irrelevant.

**PDF Source:** 26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf

applied for registration of the 
 device mark and the 
‗SWISS MILITARY‘ word mark for a variety of goods in a variety 
of classes, on ―proposed to be used‖ basis.  The applications are on 
record.  It cannot, therefore, be presumed that the appellant would not 
engage itself in manufacturing or trading activities.  In any event, the 
learned Deputy Registrar could not have returned such a finding with 
no evidence, whatsoever, to support it. 
 
91. 
For that matter, I do not see why, in facts such as these, the

nodes.title: Page 53
nodes.summary:
Based on page 53 of the provided PDF (26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf), I've extracted the following information:

**Key points:**

1. The court is considering an appeal (C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022) regarding a trade mark registration.
2. Mr. Sibal, representing the respondent, opposed the reliance on advertisements and promotional material in the case.
3. Section 9(2)(a) of the Trade Marks Act prohibits registration of marks that are "of such nature" as to deceive or cause confusion.
4. Mr. Anand, representing Armasuisse (the appellant), argued that references to usage of trade could be made under Section 1448.

**Court decision:**

1. The court agrees with Mr. Sibal and considers the manner in which a mark is used to be relevant only in determining infringement or confusion.
2. The registration of the impugned mark is on a "proposed to be used" basis, raising concerns about its use in practice.

**Relevant sections:**

1. Section 9(2)(a) - prohibits registration of marks that deceive or cause confusion
2. Section 1448 - enables the Registrar to admit evidence of usage of trade

Source: 26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf

relied on Section 1448 to justify reference to the manner in which the 
mark was being advertised and promoted by Respondent 1 as a factor 
which was required to be borne in mind even when examining the 
entitlement of the mark to registration in the face of Section 9(2)(a)6.

I find myself in agreement with Mr. Sibal.   
 
96. 
Section 1448 requires the Registrar, in any proceeding relating 
to a trade mark, to admit evidence ―of the usage of the trade 
concerned and of any relevant trade mark or trade name or get up 
legitimately used by other persons‖.  The reference to the ―usage of 
the trade concerned‖, when seen in conjunction with the immediately 
succeeding expression ―any relevant trade mark or trade name or get 
up legitimately used by other persons‖ obviously refers to the manner 
in which the trade mark, forming subject matter of the proceedings, is 
used by the trade.  Usage of the trade is a factor which, in intellectual

nodes.title: Page 55
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of Page 55 from the PDF:

**Case:** Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry (2023/DHC/000019)

**Arguments:**

* Mr. Anand (Appellant's counsel) argues that the impugned mark cannot be registered under Section 9(1)(b) of the Trade Marks Act, as it serves to designate the geographical origin of goods.
* He relies on guidelines in the Manual of Trade Marks and Registry of Trade Marks, which allegedly prohibit registration of trade marks indicating a country's name (Switzerland).

**Counter-arguments:**

* Mr. Sibal (Respondent's counsel) counters that Section 9(1)(b) does not apply to geographical indications, as this is governed by the GI Act.
* He argues that the words "SWISS MILITARY" cannot be considered as designating the geographical origin of goods.

**Relevant documents:**

* Manual of Trade Marks and Registry of Trade Marks
* GI Act

**PDF source:** 26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000019 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 & cont. matter 
Page 55 of 79 
 
 
100. Mr. Anand sought to contend that the impugned mark was not 
eligible for registration in view of Section 9(1)(b) of the Trade Marks 
Act. Section 9(1)(b) absolutely prohibits registration of trade marks 
―which consist exclusively of marks or indications which may serve in 
trade to designate‖, inter alia, the geographical origin of the goods.  
Mr. Anand‘s submission is that the impugned mark, which combines 
the white cross on a red background and the words ―Swiss Military‖ 
below it, serves in trade to designate the geographical origin of the 
goods on which the mark is affixed.  
 
101. Mr. Anand has also relied, in this context, on the guidelines 
contained in the Manual of Trade Marks and the Registry of Trade 
Marks relating to the registrations of Trade Marks which indicate the 
geographical origin of the goods.  According to Mr. Anand, under the 
said Trade Mark Manual, a trade mark which is the name of a large 
and well-known country cannot be registered at all.  Switzerland 
being a large, well-known and well populated country, Mr. Anand 
submits that the guidelines contained in the Manual on Trade Marks 
completely proscribe registration of the words ‗SWISS MILITARY‘ 
as a trade mark.  
 
102. Mr. Sibal relies, per contra, on the GI Act and the provisions 
contained therein for registration of a mark denoting the geographical 
origin of the goods. He submits that the establishment of a connection 
between the mark and the place of origin of the goods on which the 
mark is to be affixed is a pre-requisite under the GI Act, and not under 
the Trade Marks Act.  He further submits that the words ―Swiss 
Military‖ cannot, by any stretch of imagination, be regarded as 
denoting the geographical origin of the goods on which the impugned

nodes.title: Page 56
nodes.summary:
Source: Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf (PDF page 56 of 79)

**Key Points**

* The issue is whether the mark "Swiss Military" designates the geographical origin of the goods within the meaning of Section 9(1)(b) of the Trade Marks Act.
* Mr. Sibal argues that Section 9(1)(a), not applicable to "Swiss Military", applies to marks like "Made in Switzerland" on "Swiss made" marks, which unequivocally point towards geographical origin.
* The Court notes that Section 9(1)(b) is concerned with what the mark serves to designate in trade, and not with the impression it makes on consumers or third parties.

**Court Ruling**

* Section 9(1)(b) requires a strict interpretation of "geographical origin" in relation to the words "kind", "quality", etc. (noscitur a sociis & ejusdem generis).
* A mark can be said to designate geographical origin only where it unequivocally does so.

This excerpt is from the High Court of Delhi's judgment dated 4th January 2023 in the matter of C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 & cont. matter, with Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000019.
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000019 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 & cont. matter 
Page 56 of 79 
 
 
mark is to be affixed. He seeks to contradistinguish the impugned 
mark, for this purpose, with, for example, the ―Made in Switzerland‖ 
on ―Swiss made‖ marks.  Section 9(1)(a), according to Mr. Sibal, 
apply to such latter marks,  which unequivocally point towards the 
geographical origin of the goods, and not to a mark such as ―Swiss 
Military‖.  
 
103. Having heard learned Counsel, what is immediately apparent 
from a reading of Section 9(1)(b) of the Trade Marks Act is that the 
consumer or customer is a stranger to the said provision.  The 
impression of the mark on the consumer, or any other third person, is 
irrelevant, where Section 9(1)(b) is concerned.  Section 9(1)(b) is only 
concerned with what the mark serves to designate in trade. It applies 
to marks which serve, in trade, to designate, inter alia, the 
geographical origin of the goods (to the extent the provision concerns 
the controversy at hand).  
 
104. Unlike Section 9(2)(a), therefore, Section 9(1)(b) is concerned 
with what the applicant seeking registration of the mark intends to 
convey.  The word ―geographical origin‖, finding place in the 
company of the words ―kind‖, ―quality‖, ―quantity‖, ―intended 
purpose‖, ―values‖, and ―time of production‖, is required to be 
interpreted noscitur a sociis and ejusdem generis with the said 
expressions. They obviously refer to the normal recitals contained on 
packages giving particulars of the goods. In the company of these 
expressions, a mark can be said to ―designate the geographical origin‖  
of the goods only where it unequivocally does so.  Section 9(2)(a), 
would stand attracted even in a situation in which the mark, though it 
does not unequivocally indicate the geographical origin of the goods, 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:04.01.2023
15:28:31

nodes.title: Page 57
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 57 from the PDF file "26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf":

In this excerpt from a court decision (C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022), the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi rules on the registrability of a trade mark under Section 9(1)(b) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999. The court holds that the use of a white cross on a red background and the "SWISS MILITARY" logo does not serve to designate the geographical origin of goods as being from Switzerland.

Key points:

* Section 9(1)(b) would only apply if the mark serves to designate the geographical origin of goods.
* The word "designate" has a specific meaning, involving specific identification and intent to so designate.
* The court finds that the trade mark does not designate the geographical origin of goods as being from Switzerland.

PDF source: 26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf, Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000019.
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000019 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 & cont. matter 
Page 57 of 79 
 
 
may confuse the public into assuming or believing such an origin.  
Per contra, Section 9(1)(b) would apply only where the mark serves, 
in trade, to designate the geographical origin of the goods. 
 
105. In this context, the use of the word ―designate‖ is also of some 
importance.  P. Ramanatha Aiyar in his Advanced Law Lexicon, 
defines the word ―designate‖ thus: 
―To call by a distinctive title; to point out a thing by distinguishing it from 
others; to express or declare; to indicate by description or by something 
known and determinate, to point out, or mark by some particular token; to 
specify.‖ 
 
 
―Designation‖, therefore, involves specific identification, with a 
declaratory component.  The word ―designate‖ is far more specific 
than the word ―indicate‖.  Designation involves a positive act done by 
the person who designates.  Additionally, it involves the intent to so 
designate.  It is only, therefore, where the trade mark, of which 
registration is sought, consists exclusively of marks or indications 
which are intended to identify the geographical origin of the goods in 
trade, that the mark becomes non-registrable under Section 9(1)(b) (to 
the extent it is relevant for our purpose).  
 
106. Read thus, it cannot be held that the use of the white cross on a 
red background, or the ‗SWISS MILITARY‘ logo below it, serves in 
trade to designate the geographical origin of the goods as being 
Switzerland.   The possibility of such a mark confusing or deceiving 
the public into believing that the goods are of Swiss origin when, in 
fact, they are not, may fatally imperil the entitlement of the mark to 
registration in view of Section 9(1)(a) of the Trade Marks Act; 
Section 9(1)(b) would not, however, stand attracted on that ground.  
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:04.01.2023

nodes.title: Page 58
nodes.summary:
Summary of page 58 from PDF `26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf`:

Page 58 refers to the case of Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr (C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022). Key points:

* The court was considering whether the mark "Swiss Military" is eligible for registration under Section 9(1)(b) of the Trade Marks Act.
* The court did not deem it necessary to advert to guidelines issued by the Trade Mark Registry regarding registration of marks indicating geographical origin, as they seem inapplicable to this case (p. 58).
* Section 9(1)(b) does not render the impugned mark ineligible for registration.
* Emphasis was placed on the distinction between "absolute grounds" (Section 9) and "relative grounds" (Section 11) for refusal of registration.

PDF source: `26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf` (available through online search).
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000019 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 & cont. matter 
Page 58 of 79 
 
 
107. In that view of the matter, I do not deem it necessary to advert 
to the Guidelines issued by the Trade Mark Registry for registration of 
marks which indicate the geographical origin of goods.  In any event, 
the applicability of the said guidelines seems questionable, as they 
refer to use of names of places, countries, rivers, etc., as trademarks, 
and do not seem to apply to the use of a mark such as ―Swiss 
Military‖.  The decision in Imperial Tobacco10, on which Mr. Anand 
relies, too, concerns itself with the entitlement, to registration, of the 
word ‗Shimla‘, which is the name of a place. 
 
108. Section 9(1)(b) of the Trade Marks Act, therefore, does not 
render the impugned mark ineligible for registration  as a trade mark. 
 
IV. 
Re: Section 11(3)(a)7 
 
109. Much emphasis was placed, by Mr. Sibal, on the fact that, while 
the grounds for refusal of registration envisaged by Section 9 were 
―absolute grounds‖ those envisaged by Section 11 were ―relative 
grounds‖.  His submission is that ―relative grounds‖ would refer to 
grounds which consider the mark, of which registration is being 
sought, in relation to some other mark. Adverting specifically to 
Section 11(3)(a), Mr. Sibal seeks to submit that the words ―by virtue 
of any law‖ with which the said provision commences, have to be 
read in the context of Section 11  as a whole and also noscitur a sociis 
with the words ―law of passing off‖ and the ―law of copyright‖ which 
find place in Clauses (a) and (b) of Section 11(3).  He has also pressed 
into service, in this context, Section 11(5)26 of the Trade Marks Act.

nodes.title: Page 59
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 59 from the PDF "Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf":

**Context:** Court case C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 

**Page Content:**

Mr. Anand argues that the words "by virtue of any law" in Section 11(3)(a) are all-encompassing and would include the Geneva Convention Act.

However, upon deeper analysis, the court agrees with Mr. Sibal's interpretation that the provisions need clarification.

The court notes that Section 11(3)(a) is a poorly worded provision that lacks precision.

If Mr. Anand's submission was accepted, it would imply that all laws applicable in India would be included, including the Geneva Convention Act.

**References:**

* Court case: C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 
* PDF source: Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr (2023/DHC/000019)
* Relevant page: Page 59 of 79
* Key dates:
	+ Reserved on 14th December 2022
	+ Pronounced on 4th January 2023

110. Mr. Anand contends, per contra, that the words ―by virtue of 
any law‖ are wide and all encompassing. The mere fact that the law of 
passing off has been particularized after the said expression in Section 
11(3)(a) cannot, in his submission, narrow the sweep and ambit of the 
words ―any law‖. ―Any law‖, in Mr. Anand‘s submission, would refer 
precisely to ―any law‖, meaning any law in force for the time being in 
India.  The Geneva Convention Act is also, therefore, according to 
him, one of the laws which would stand embraced by the expression 
―any law‖ as used in Section 11(3)(a).   
 
111. I must confess that the submissions of Mr. Anand did initially 
appeal to me.  On a deeper analysis of Section 11, however, I find 
myself in agreement with Mr. Sibal. 
 
112. Section 11(3)(a), I may note, is a very unhappily worded 
provision.  It is lacking in precision, which is one of the most essential 
attributes of good legislation.  I have, however, to interpret the 
provision as it stands.   
 
113. If one were to accept Mr. Anand‘s submission, the words ―by 
virtue of any law‖ would encompass every law applicable in the 
territory of India.  In that event, the Geneva Convention Act would 
also be one such law.   
 
114. In its recent judgment in Renaissance Hotel Holdings Inc. v. 
B. Vijaya Sai49, a Bench of three Hon‘ble Judges of the Supreme

nodes.title: Page 60
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 60 from the PDF:

**In the High Court of Delhi**

**Case No:** C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 & cont. matter
** Neutral Citation Number :** 2023/DHC/000019  

On page 60, the court refers to two important principles of interpretation while considering a case involving a trade mark registry dispute between Armasuisse and the Trade Mark Registry.

**Textual and Contextual Interpretation**

The court notes that the High Court failed to consider these principles in its previous judgment. It quotes from Judgment of RBI v. Peerless General Finance & Investment Co. Ltd. (1987) 1 SCC 424, which emphasizes the importance of:

*   Interpreting a statute by considering both text and context
*   Looking at a statute as a whole to understand each section, clause, phrase, and word in its place
*   Considering the reasons behind the enactment of the statute while interpreting it.

The court further observes that statutes should not be construed in isolation but with reference to their entire scheme and purpose.

Interpretation must depend on the text and the

say if the text is the texture, context is what gives the

nodes.title: Page 61
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 61 from the PDF:

**Case:** Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.

**Page 61:** The court criticizes the High Court for incorrectly interpreting Sections 29 and 30 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999.

**Key points:**

1. **Wholesome interpretation required**: The court emphasizes that a section should be read as a whole, considering all its parts together.
2. **Ignoring context is not permissible**: The court argues that giving a textual meaning to provisions without considering their context would be incorrect.
3. **High Court's errors:** The High Court failed to notice that:
	* A part of a section cannot be read in isolation (Balasinor Nagrik Coop. Bank Ltd. v. Babubhai Shankerlal Pandya, 1987 SCC).
	* Sub-sections must be considered as a whole.
4. **Legislative scheme**: The court notes that the Trade Marks Act is designed to regulate trade mark management and provide rights for registered proprietors.

**Source:** PDF: Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr., 2023/DHC/000019 (High Court of Delhi)

References:

* Balasinor Nagrik Coop. Bank Ltd. v. Babubhai Shankerlal Pandya, 1987 SCC
* Kalawatibai v. Soiryabai, 1991 SCC
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000019 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 & cont. matter 
Page 61 of 79 
 
 
globalisation of trade and industry, the need to encourage 
investment flows and transfer of technology, and the need for 
simplification and harmonisation of trade mark management 
systems. One of the purposes for which the said Act has been 
enacted is prohibiting the use of someone else's trade mark as a 
part of the corporate name or the name of business concern. If the 
entire scheme of the Act is construed as a whole, it provides for the 
rights conferred by registration and the right to sue for 
infringement of the registered trade mark by its proprietor. The 
legislative scheme as enacted under the said statute elaborately 
provides for the eventualities in which a proprietor of the 
registered trade mark can bring an action for infringement of the 
trade mark and the limits on effect of the registered trade mark. By 
picking up a part of the provisions in sub-section (4) of Section 29 
of the said Act and a part of the provision in sub-section (1) of 
Section 30 of the said Act and giving it a textual meaning without 
considering the context in which the said provisions have to be 
construed, in our view, would not be permissible. We are at pains 
to say that the High Court fell in error in doing so. 
 
67.  
Another principle that the High Court has failed to notice is 
that a part of a section cannot be read in isolation. This Court, 
speaking through A.P. Sen, J., in Balasinor Nagrik Coop. Bank 
Ltd. v. Babubhai Shankerlal Pandya52, observed thus :  
 
―4. … It is an elementary rule that construction of a section 
is to be made of all parts together. It is not permissible to 
omit any part of it. For, the principle that the statute must 
be read as a whole is equally applicable to different parts 
of the same section.‖ 
 
This 
principle 
was 
reiterated 
by 
this 
Court 
in Kalawatibai v. Soiryabai53: 
 
―6. … It is well settled that a section has to be read in its 
entirety as one composite unit without bifurcating it or 
ignoring any part of it.” 
 
68.  
Ignoring this principle, the High Court has picked up clause 
(c) of sub-section (4) of Section 29 of the said Act in isolation 
without even noticing the other provisions contained in the said 
sub-section (4) of Section 29 of the said Act. Similarly, again 
while considering the import of sub-section (1) of Section 30 of the 
said Act, the High Court has only picked up clause (b) of sub-
section (1) of Section 30 of the said Act, ignoring the provisions 
contained in clause (a) of the said sub-section (1) of Section 30 of 
the said Act.‖ 
(Emphasis supplied)

Here is a summary of page 62 from the PDF "26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf":

**Page Content:**

The court emphasizes the importance of interpreting statutory provisions in context, taking into account both the text and surrounding sections.

**Key Points:**

1. The expression "by virtue of any law" in Section 11(3)(a) should not be interpreted in isolation but in relation to the entire section.
2. Section 11(1-3) outlines various grounds for refusal of trade mark registration, including likelihood of confusion and protection of unregistered trade marks.
3. The court must consider the entirety of Section 11 when interpreting its provisions.

**References:**

Section 11(1-3) of the Trade Marks Act is mentioned in relation to relative grounds for refusal of registration.

120. Section 11(2) protects earlier ―well-known trade marks‖, within 
the meaning of Section 2(1)(zg)55 of the Trade Marks Act. Where an 
earlier trade mark is a well-known trade mark within the said 
definition, a later trade mark, which is identical or similar to the

the law of passing off‖ or ―by virtue of law of copyright‖.

11, therefore, refer to handicaps on registration in the light of earlier 
existing intellectual property.  Clearly, they are intended at protecting 
existing intellectual property, essentially either from infringement or 
from passing off.

nodes.title: Page 64
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 64 from the PDF "26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf":

The page discusses Section 9 of the Trademarks Act, which prescribes conditions for registration of trademarks. According to Section 9(1), marks are not registrable if they are:

* devoid of distinctive character (Section 9(1)(a))
* consist exclusively of descriptive or common indications (Section 9(1)(b))
* customary to the trade (publici juris) (Section 9(1)(c))

Additionally, Section 9(2) lists conditions that make a mark registrable, including:

* which deceive the public or cause confusion (Section 9(2)(a))
* contains matter likely to hurt religious susceptibilities (Section 9(2)(b))
* comprises scandalous or obscene matter (Section 9(2)(c))

The page concludes with Section 9(3), which deals with shapes of goods that are not registrable.

nodes.title: Page 65
nodes.summary:
**Summary of Page 65 from PDF: Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf**

On page 65, the court delivers its decision in relation to Section 9 of the Trademarks Act:

* The proscription under Section 9 relates to the character of the mark itself, not other marks.
* If a mark suffers from any disqualifications under Section 9, it cannot be registered.
* The likelihood of deception and confusion (Section 9(2)(a)) must be an attribute of the mark itself.

Additionally, on page 65-68:

* Sections 9 and 11 apply to different grounds for refusing registration: absolute grounds under Section 9, and relative grounds under Section 11.
* The words "by virtue of any law" in Section 11(3)(a) relate to laws protecting existing intellectual property.

This summary focuses on the legal facts, proceedings, arguments, decisions, dates, names, and amounts mentioned on page 65. (Source: Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf, Case No. C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022, Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000019)
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000019 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 & cont. matter 
Page 65 of 79 
 
 
In each case, therefore, the proscription under Section 9 relates to the 
character of the mark itself, vis-à-vis the goods on which it is used.  If 
the mark, by its very nature and on its own, suffers from any of the 
disqualifications envisaged by Section 9, it cannot be registered.  No 
occasion arises, therefore, under Section 9, to refer to any other mark.  
Mr. Sibal is, therefore, correct in his submission that the likelihood of 
deception and confusion envisaged by Section 9(2)(a), too, has to be 
an attribute of the mark itself and seen on its own, and not in 
comparison with, or vis-à-vis, any other mark.  It is for this reason that 
the clause employs the expression ―by its very nature‖.   
 
124. Section 9, therefore, applies to inherent attributes of the 
applicant mark, of its own, whereas Section 9 applies to attributes of 
the mark vis-à-vis existing marks of others.  Ergo, Section 9 contains 
―absolute‖ grounds to refuse registration, whereas Section 11 contains 
―relative‖ grounds to do so. 
 
125. Even read in the context of Sections 11(1) and 11(2) and the 
other clauses of Section 11(3), or vis-à-vis Section 9, therefore, the 
words ―by virtue of any law‖, as used in Section 11(3)(a), would 
appear to apply only to law which relates to protection of existing 
intellectual property of others.  
 
126. Section 11(5), on which Mr. Sibal rightly relies, sets the issue, 
in a way, at rest.  
 
127. Section 11(5) is couched in mandatory terms, as is apparent 
from the use of the word ―shall‖. It states that registration of a mark 
―shall not be refused ... on the grounds specified in sub-sections (2)

nodes.title: Page 66
nodes.summary:
Based on page 66 of the PDF "26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf" (Source: High Court of Delhi at New Delhi), I have summarized the following facts:

**Case No:** C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022
**Citation Number:** 2023/DHC/000019

**Relevant Paragraphs:**

* The pre-condition for Sections 11(2) and 11(3) to apply requires an opposition by a proprietor of an earlier trade mark (Paragraph 128).
* An objection from the proprietor of the earlier trade mark is necessary to refuse registration under Sections 11(2) and 11(3) (Paragraph 129).
*

**Key Points:**

* The legislative intent is to balance the rights of the applicant with those of the earlier mark proprietor.
* Use of the article "the" in Section 11(5) indicates its application to proprietorial rights vested in an earlier trade mark.

Note that this summary focuses on only two paragraphs (128-130) from page 66 and does not cover the entire PDF content.

Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000019 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 & cont. matter 
Page 66 of 79 
 
 
and (3)‖ unless the proprietor of ―the earlier trade mark‖ opposes the 
registration on one or more of the grounds envisaged by Sections 
11(2) and 11(3). The right to refuse registration of a mark under 
Section 11(3), therefore, is subject to the pre-condition envisaged by 
Section 11(5) applying.  It is only where the proprietor of an earlier 
trade mark objects to registration of the proposed mark on one of the 
grounds envisaged by Sections 11(2) and 11(3), in appropriate 
opposition proceedings, that registration of a mark can be refused 
under either of the said provisions.  
 
128. This places the matter beyond pale of doubt.  The pre-condition 
for Sections 11(2) and 11 (3) to apply, as statutorily engrafted in 
Section 11(5), requires an opposition by a proprietor of an earlier 
trade mark.  The proprietor of the earlier trade mark has, therefore, to 
object to registration of the proposed mark on the ground (i) that it is 
identical with or similar to an earlier well-known trade mark, (ii) the 
use of the mark in India is liable to be prevented by any law, in 
particular the law of passing off or (iii) the use of the mark in India is 
liable to be prevented by the law of copyright.  
 
129. The legislative intent, clearly, is to balance the right of an 
applicant seeking registration of the later mark, with the intellectual 
property rights which vest in the proprietor of the earlier mark.    
 
130. This conclusion is also supported by the use of the particular 
article ―the‖ used in the expression ―the earlier trade mark‖ in Section 
11(5).  The use of the article ―the‖ indicates that all proscriptions in 
Sections 11(5) (2) and (3) are intended to apply to proprietorial rights 
vesting in the proprietor of an earlier trade mark.  
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:04.01.2023
15:28:31
Signature Not Verified

nodes.title: Page 67
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 67 from the PDF "26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf" in approximately 200 words:

The High Court of Delhi at New Delhi was considering an appeal from Armasuisse (Appellant) against the Registrar of Trademarks' decision to refuse registration of its mark. On page 67, the court was interpreting Section 11(3)(a) of the Trade Marks Act, which allows refusal of registration if it is contrary to any law in force in India.

The court ruled that the words "any law" in Section 11(3)(a) cannot be understood as referring to every law in force in India. If so, it would make the provision absolute and illogical, as it would restrict the right to object to registration only to proprietors of earlier trade marks (Section 11(5)). The court also considered Renaissance Hotels Holdings v. Portman Resorts Group  (para 66-68), which reinforced that the sweep of Section 11(3)(a) must be restricted to laws impacting proprietorial rights.

The words "by virtue of any law" in Section 11(3)(a) cannot be extended to every applicable law in India, but only to those affecting proprietary rights. This interpretation is based on a reading of the section in conjunction with Section 9 and other provisions of Section 11.

(PDF source: Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000019 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 & cont. matter 
Page 67 of 79 
 
 
131. The words ―any law‖, as employed in Section 11(3)(a), would 
also, therefore, have to be understood in this background. They cannot 
be understood as referring to any law in force in India, which has 
nothing to do with intellectual property rights vesting in the proprietor 
of any earlier mark.  
 
132. As Mr. Sibal correctly submits, if the word ―any law‖, finding 
place in Section 11(3)(a) is to embrace all laws in force in India, the 
proscription would cease to be ―relative‖, and would become 
―absolute‖.  It would, then, appropriately have to find place in Section 
9, not in Section 11.  Additionally, if such were the interpretation, it 
would be illogical to restrict the right to object to registration, on that 
ground, only to proprietors of earlier trade marks, as Section 11(5) 
ordains.  The fact that Section 11(3) applies only where an objection 
to registration, on the grounds envisaged in the said sub-sections, is 
raised by the proprietor of an earlier trade mark, indicates that the 
provision does not envisage an absolute ground to refuse registration, 
but envisages, instead, an objection predicated on the prejudice 
suffered by the intellectual property rights of the proprietor of the 
earlier trade mark.   
 
133. It is not necessary, therefore, for me to venture into noscitur a 
sociis territory as, even read in conjunction with Section 9 and the 
other provisions of Section 11, in the light of the principles enunciated 
in paras 66 to 68 of Renaissance Hotels Holdings49, the words ―by 
virtue of any law‖, as employed in Section 11(3)(a), cannot be 
extended to embrace every law applicable in the territory of India. 
Their sweep has to be restricted to laws which impact proprietorial 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:04.01.2023
15:28:31
Signature Not Verified

nodes.title: Page 68
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 68 from the PDF "26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf":

The Court has rejected the objection by Armsasuisse (Appellant) regarding registration of an impugned mark under Section 11(3) of the Trade Marks Act.

Key points:

* The legislative intent was to restrict the proscriptions against registration to intellectual property rights available in India.
* Section 11(5) allows registration of a new trademark if the proprietor of an earlier trademark does not object.
* Armsasuisse is not the proprietor of an earlier trademark, so registration of the impugned mark cannot be refused based on Sections 11(2) or 11(3).
* The learned Deputy Registrar was correct in declining the objection by Armsasuisse.

Relevant legal facts and proceedings:

* Case No: C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 & cont. matter
* Date of Pronouncement: January 4, 2023
* Court: HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI

Source: PDF "26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf"
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000019 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 & cont. matter 
Page 68 of 79 
 
 
intellectual property rights vested in the proprietor of an earlier trade 
mark, as is specifically ordained by Section 11(5).  
 
134. The 13th Lok Sabha debates, on which both sides placed 
reliance, fortify the conclusion.  Despite a specific recommendation, 
in the Debates, to further elaborate Clause 11(3)(a) of the Trade 
Marks Bill – which metamorphosed into Section 11(3)(a) of the Trade 
Marks Act after Presidential sanction – to protect India‘s 
commitments under the Universal and Berne Copyright Conventions, 
and its obligations under the TRIPS agreement, these suggestions 
were never acted upon.  The legislative intent was always, therefore, 
to restrict the proscriptions against registration to the intellectual 
property rights available under intellectual property legislation in 
India.    
 
135. In that view of the matter, the learned Deputy Registrar cannot 
be faulted in declining the objection of the appellant against 
registration of the impugned mark, predicated on Section 11(3) of the 
Trade Marks Act.  
 
136. Besides, and even otherwise, Mr. Sibal is also correct on facts 
in pointing out that the appellant is not a proprietor of an earlier trade 
mark. Clearly, therefore, in view of Section 11(5), the registration of 
the impugned mark, as sought by the Respondent 2, could not have 
been refused by the learned Deputy Registrar under Sections 11(2) or 
11(3) at the instance of the appellant.  
 
V. 
Power of the learned Deputy Registrar to consider other laws 
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:04.01.2023
15:28:31

nodes.title: Page 69
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 69 from the PDF document "26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf":

**Context:** C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 & cont. matter, Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000019

**Content:**

* The Court discusses whether a trade mark can be registered if its use is proscribed by another law (German Conventions Act).
* Mr. Anand argues that the Geneva Conventions Act prohibits the use of the mark.
* The Registrar's power and authority are circumscribed by the provisions of the Trade Marks Act.

**Key Legal Facts:**

* Section 11(3)(a) does not extend to statutes involving intellectual property rights of others, excluding the Geneva Conventions Act from its scope.
* The Registrar is appointed for the purposes of the Trade Marks Act (Section 3(1)56).
* Previous judgments (M.A. Kochu Devassy v. State of Kerala and Ashok Leyland Ltd v. State of Tamil Nadu) hold that "for the purpose of this Act" means all provisions, not just some.

**Date:** Pronounced on January 4, 2023

PDF Source: "26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf"
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000019 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 & cont. matter 
Page 69 of 79 
 
 
137. I have held, earlier, that the words ―any law‖, in Section 
11(3)(a) cannot extend to statutes which do not involve considerations 
of intellectual property rights of others and that, therefore, the Geneva 
Conventions Act does not fall within the parenthetic embrace of the 
phrase ―any law‖.  But what if the use of the mark, of which 
registration is sought, is absolutely proscribed by some other law, as 
the German Conventions Act does in the present case, according to 
Mr. Anand?  Can the Registrar register a mark the use of which stands 
statutorily proscribed elsewhere? 
 
138. The answer, in my view, has to be in the affirmative.  The 
Registrar of Trade Marks is appointed under Section 3(1)56 of the 
Trade Marks Act, and the learned Deputy Registrar, who has passed 
the impugned order, has apparently been empowered to do so by the 
Act.  In either case, the appointment of the officer is ―for the purposes 
of this Act‖.  In M.A. Kochu Devassy v. State of Kerala57, the 
Supreme Court held that the expression ― ‗for the purposes of the Act‘ 
surely means for the purposes of all and not only some of the 
provisions of the Act.‖  The expression ―for the purpose of the said 
Act‖ was understood, in Ashok Leyland Ltd v. State of Tamil Nadu58 
as ―for the purpose of all the provisions of the said Act‖.   
 
139. The power and authority of the learned Registrar, therefore, 
stand circumscribed by the provisions of the Trade Marks Act.   He is 
appointed for discharging functions under the Act, and is the 
administrative, and quasi-judicial, modus for grant of registration to 
                                          
56 3.  
Appointment of Registrar and other officers. –   
(1) 
The Central Government may, by notification in the Official Gazette, appoint a person to 
be known as the Controller-General of Patents, Designs and Trade Marks, who shall be the 
Registrar of Trade Marks for the purposes of this Act. 
57 (1979) 2 SCC 117 : AIR 1979 SC 358

By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:04.01.2023
15:28:31

nodes.title: Page 70
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 70 from the PDF "26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf":

The judgment discusses the scope of inquiry into entitlement for trade mark registration. It states that the Trade Marks Act forms a composite code in this matter, and therefore, the Deputy Registrar should not travel outside its scope in search of other statutory fetters on registration.

Key points from page 70:

* The learned Deputy Registrar's authority to refuse registration is limited by Sections 9-16 of the Trade Marks Act.
* Section 23(1) mandates registration once opposition has been decided in favor of the applicant.
* There are no express proscriptions against the Deputy Registrar seeking other statutory fetters, but they must be considered within the scope of the Trade Marks Act.

PDF source: "26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf"
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000019 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 & cont. matter 
Page 70 of 79 
 
 
trade marks and performing all functions ancillary thereto.  The 
sphere of his authority, in the matter of refusal of registration cannot, 
therefore, extend beyond Sections 9 to 16 of the Trade Marks Act, of 
which Sections 9 and 11 contain the absolute and relative grounds on 
which registration can be refused.  Section 23(1)59 mandates that, 
where the registration of the mark has been opposed and the 
opposition has been decided in favour of the applicant, the mark shall 
be registered.  No discretion vests in the learned Deputy Registrar, 
once the opposition is decided in favour of the applicant seeking 
registration.   
 
140. Though, therefore, the Trade Marks Act does not contain any 
express proscription against the learned Deputy Registrar travelling 
outside its scope in search of any other possible statutory fetters on 
registration, it is clear that, holistically read, the Trade Marks Act 
forms a composite and self-contained code, in the matter of 
registration.  The learned Deputy Registrar has, therefore, to limit the 
scope of inquiry, into the entitlement of the proposed mark to 
registration, to the considerations that find place in the Trade Marks 
Act, and cannot travel outside it. 
 
VI. 
Section 12 of the Geneva Convention Act, independently seen

(a)  
the application has not been opposed and the time for notice of opposition has 
expired; or

the application has been opposed and the opposition has been decided in favour 
of the applicant, 
the Registrar shall, unless the Central Government otherwise directs, register the said trade 
mark within eighteen months of the filing of the application and the trade mark when registered 
shall be registered as of the date of the making of the said application and that date shall, subject to 
the provisions of Section 154, be deemed to be the date of registration.

nodes.title: Page 71
nodes.summary:
**Summary of Page 71 from Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr**

Source: 26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf (PDF)

On page 71, the Judge discusses Section 12 of the Geneva Conventions Act and its relation to trade mark registration.

Key points:

* The Judge concludes that the Geneva Conventions Act does not affect the right to registration of a trade mark.
* The right to use a trade mark is separate from the right to register it (Section 28(1) of the Trade Marks Act).
* No external proscription against registering a trade mark exists, as argued by Mr. Anand (learned counsel for the Respondent).

Key citations:

* Section 12 of the Geneva Conventions Act
* Section 28(1) of the Trade Marks Act

Key dates: 

* Not mentioned in this specific page.
 
Other mentions:

* None relevant to this summary.
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000019 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 & cont. matter 
Page 71 of 79 
 
 
141. The above conclusion would stand fortified even by Section 12 
of the Geneva Conventions Act itself.  What Section 12 proscribes is 
use of the heraldic emblem of the Swiss confederation.  There is a 
statutory distinction between registration and use of a trade mark.  
Use follows registration.  Section 28(1)60 of the Trade Marks Act 
makes this clear.  The proprietor of a registered trade mark is, by 
Section 28(1), invested with the right to use it.  Section 12 of the 
Geneva Conventions Act, therefore, affects, if at all, the right to use 
the mark, not the right to have it registered.  The right to registration 
stands circumscribed by the Trade Marks Act, which remains a 
complete code in that regard.  If the right to use the mark, once 
registered, is subject to some other statutory proscription, that 
proscription operates outside the peripheries of the Trade Marks Act.  
If such a proscription exists, and the proprietor of the trade mark 
violates it, the violation may well invite sanctions as envisaged by the 
proscribing statute.  The right to registration of the mark is unaffected 
by any such proscription.  The learned Deputy Registrar, and, 
consequently, this Court which is sitting in appeal over the decision of 
the learned Deputy Registrar, is not required to venture into that 
territory, as it is concerned only with the entitlement of the impugned 
mark to registration, and not to the entitlement of Respondent 2 to use 
the mark, once registered if at all.   
 
142. To my knowledge, there does not exist, outside the Trade 
Marks Act, any proscription against registration of a trade mark.  Nor 
has Mr. Anand invited my attention to any such proscription. 
                                          
60 28.  
Rights conferred by registration. –  
(1)  
Subject to the other provisions of this Act, the registration of a trade mark shall, if valid, 
give to the registered proprietor of the trade mark the exclusive right to the use of the trade mark in 
relation to the goods or services in respect of which the trade mark is registered and to obtain relief 
in respect of infringement of the trade mark in the manner provided by this Act. 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:04.01.2023
15:28:31

nodes.title: Page 72
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 72 from the PDF:

**Neutral Citation Number**: 2023/DHC/000019
**C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) No.**: 158/2022 & cont.

**Page 72 Content**

The court discusses two issues:

1. **Misrepresentation with color limitation on trademark registration**: The deputy registrar allowed the registration of the impugned mark without limitation of color, which means it also registered the mark with a white cross on red background. This decision is not sustainable because:
	* When used for goods of Chinese origin, it would be a "false trade description" under Section 2(1)(i)(IV) and ineligible for registration.
	* It would also be ineligible for registration under Section 9(2)(a) of the Trade Marks Act.

2. **Tax Invoice dated 12th July 2008**: Mr. Anand argued that this invoice was fabricated because it used the ₹ symbol two years before its official notification in a Cabinet Circular in July 2010. The government software used by Respondent 1 may have employed the ₹ symbol for the Indian Rupee.

**Source:** Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr, C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022, PDF (pages 72-79).
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000019 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 & cont. matter 
Page 72 of 79 
 
 
VII. Other Issues 
 
143. The impugned order of the Learned Deputy Registrar allows the 
registration of the impugned 
 mark without limitation of colour.  
By application of Section 10(2) of the Trade Marks Act, therefore, it 
also registers the mark with a white cross on red background, as  
.  
To that extent, the imugned order is not sustainable, as  
(i) 
the 
 mark, when used for goods of Chinese origin, would 
amount to a ―false trade description‖ within the meaning of Section 
2(1)(i)(IV), and would therefore be ineligible to registration, and 
(ii) 
the mark would additionally be ineligible to registration under 
Section 9(2)(a) of the Trade Marks Act. 
 
VII.1 Re. Tax Invoice dated 12th July 2008 
 
144. Relying on Cabinet Circular dated 15th July 2010, which 
officially notified the ₹ symbol for the Indian Rupee, Mr. Anand 
sought to contend that Tax Invoice dated 12th July 2008 was 
fabricated, as it used the said ₹ symbol two years prior thereto.  The 
submission, though seemingly fragile, is not without significance.  
The only response of Mr. Sibal, to this submission, was that the 
software used by Respondent 1 was employing the ₹ symbol for the 
Indian Rupee.  In fact, web research reveals that the ₹ sign was 
shortlisted from the entries received pursuant to a contest for 
submitting entries for a new symbol for the Indian Rupee announced 
by the Indian Government on 5th January 2009.  Out of 3331 
responses received, five were shortlisted, from which the ₹ symbol 
was selected in a meeting held of the Union Council of Ministers held

nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 73 from the PDF "26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf":

**Court Case:** C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022, I.A. 20094/2022, I.A. 20095/2022 and I.A. 20096/2022

**Appellant:** Armasuisse

**Respondent:** Trade Mark Registry & Anr.

**Page 73 of 79:**

* Respondent 2 (Trade Mark Registry) was asked to explain how a Tax Invoice bearing the ₹ symbol was issued on July 12, 2008.
* Respondent 2 failed to provide a satisfactory explanation, and their response that it was a feature of the software used is considered unsatisfactory.
* The court notes that Respondent 2's submission that the contention was irrelevant because they applied for the mark on a "proposed to be used" basis has no merit.

**Key Points:**

* Date: July 12, 2008
* Symbol: ₹ (Rupee symbol)
* Software feature cited as explanation

**PDF source:** 26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000019 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 & cont. matter 
Page 73 of 79 
 
 
on 15th July 2010.  Respondent 2 would, therefore, have to explain, 
satifactorily, how the Tax Invoice, bearing the ₹ symbol, came to be 
issued by it on 12th July 2008.   
 
145. Respondent 2 has failed to do so.  Though the point was raised 
before the learned Deputy Registrar, albeit in written submissions 
after conclusion of hearing, no reply, to the point, was provided by 
Respondent 2.  The point has again been urged in these proceedings 
by the appellant, and the only explanation forthcoming, from 
Respondent 2, is that it was a feature of the software used by it.  The 
reply is thoroughly unsatisfactory.  The developers of the software 
cannot be presumed to be blessed with the gift of clairvoyance, to be 
able to divine the symbol that would be adopted for the Indian rupee 
even before suggestions for suitable symbols were invited by the 
Government from the public.   
 
146. Prima facie, therefore, Respondent 2 has failed to satisfactorily 
rebut the appellant‘s contention regarding the Tax Invoice dated 12th 
July 2008.  The submission, of Respondent 2, that the contention was 
irrelevant as it had applied for the impugned mark on a ―proposed to 
be used‖ basis is obviously without merit.  Submission of a fabricated 
document for having a mark registered would ipso facto disentitle the 
applicant to registration.  The matter cannot be wished away by 
referring to any number of other invoices which Respondent 2 might 
have submitted in support of its application for registration.  One 
single fabricated document is itself sufficient to reject the application.  
No benefit, in law, can enure in favour of a fabricator.  The hands of 
one who seeks a benefit, which the law provides, have to be clean. 
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:04.01.2023
15:28:31

The Hon'ble Court on Page 74 observes that:

* The factor of trade mark usage in a black-and-white format (Page 73) cannot be determinative on its own, as it was raised by the appellant after the hearing had concluded.

147. Having said that, I do not deem it appropriate to use this factor 
as determinative of the issue in controversy, as it was, in fact, raised
