during the proceedings before him, Respondent 2 would have had a

nodes.title: Page 75
nodes.summary:
**Summary of Page 75 from PDF: Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.**

Source: Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000019 (C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 & cont. matter)

The Hon'ble High Court of Delhi was considering the validity of the trademark "SWISS MILITARY" used by Respondent 2. On page 75, the court held:

* The mark "SWISS MILITARY" is capable of causing confusion among the public as it evokes an instant mental picture of the Swiss military establishment, leading to a connection with Switzerland.
* This constitutes a clear instance of "causing confusion", satisfying Section 9(2)(a) of the Trademarks Act.
* The Slazenger principle applies here, indicating that Respondent 2 has no explanation for adopting the "SWISS MILITARY" moniker.

The court's decision was delivered on January 4, 2023.
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000019 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 & cont. matter 
Page 75 of 79 
 
 
black-and-white? 
 
151. The answer should be obvious. 
 
152. Section 9(2)(a) uses the words ―of such nature as to deceive the 
public or cause confusion‖.  I have already held that the impugned 
mark, when used in a red-and-white colour format, is of such nature as 
to confuse the public into linking the goods, on which the mark 
figures, with Switzerland; in other words, of presuming the goods to 
be of Swiss origin.   
 
153. This impression is not attributable solely to the red-and-white 
colour scheme of the mark.  The words ‗SWISS MILITARY‘ have a 
large part to play in the impression that the mark would carry.  It 
would be folly to analogize a mark such as ‗SWISS MILITARY‘ 
with a mark such as, for example, ‗PETER ENGLAND‘ which, as a 
phrase has no etymological meaning at all, so that it it becomes 
instantly fanciful, and can, therefore, be kept out of the reckoning.  
‗SWISS MILITARY‘, however, conjures up an instant mental 
picture of the Swiss military establishment.  A mental connection with 
Switzerland is, therefore, inevitably made.  That, by itself, satisfies the 
requirement of ―causing confusion‖ envisaged by Section 9(2)(a).   
 
154. The Slazenger38 principle would also equally apply here.   
There is no explanation for the adoption, by Respondent 2, of the 
‗SWISS MILITARY‘ moniker.  The use of the word ‗MILITARY‘ is 
seriously prejudicial to the case of Respondent 2.  It is not a word 
lightly used, or, for that matter, to be lightly used.  The pleadings of 
Respondent 2 do not throw light on the motivation for adoption of the

nodes.title: Page 76
nodes.summary:
Unfortunately, I was not able to access the entire PDF document as it is a court ruling and may be subject to copyright restrictions. However, based on your request, here is a summary of page 76 from the provided snippet:

**Case: Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr**

**Page 76:**

The Deputy Registrar had rejected the registration of the mark "SWISS MILITARY" under Section 9(2)(a) of the Trade Marks Act, as it is of a nature which cannot be registered in accordance with its provisions.

**Rationale:**

* The learned judge disagreed with the Deputy Registrar's presumption that ordinary consumers would not connect the goods bearing the mark "SWISS MILITARY" with the Swiss military establishment.
* The words "SWISS MILITARY", like "INDIAN AIR FORCE", carry a solemn connotation and are unlikely to be used for ordinary commercially traded goods unconnected with the respective national forces.

**Source:** Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr, [2023/DHC/000019], Page 76 of 79 from PDF: 26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf

Please note that this is a summary based on a limited snippet and may not be comprehensive or entirely accurate without access to the full document.

nodes.title: Page 77
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 77 from PDF "26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf":

**Summary**

On Page 77, the Court discusses the registration of a trade mark "SWISS MILITARY" by Respondent 2 without any cross (either black and white or red and white). The Counsel for Respondent 2, Mr. Anirudh Bakhru, argues that there are two distinguishing features in this case:

1. The mark does not use the official Swiss insignia.
2. The "SWISS MILITARY" mark independently is unlikely to cause confusion with other marks.

The Court notes that if the impugned order allows registration without limitation of color, both versions (red and white or black and white) would be ineligible for registration as trade marks, making the order unsustainable in law.

**Key Facts**

* Respondent 2's mark: "SWISS MILITARY"
* Counsel: Mr. Anirudh Bakhru
* Distinguishing features: Official Swiss insignia not used; mark's independence from cross

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
The document is a court decision (C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 & cont. matter) from the High Court of Delhi, dated January 4, 2023, in the case of Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr. (Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000019). The court was considering an appeal by ArmAsuisse against the registration of three trademarks, , and "SWISS MILITARY", for use on textiles.

Key Facts and Decisions:

* The court was reserved on December 14, 2022, and pronounced its decision on January 4, 2023.
* ArmAsuisse had filed an appeal (CA(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022) against the registration of the three trademarks, arguing that they were ineligible for registration due to their similarity with existing marks.
* The court found that the use of the "SWISS MILITARY" appellation has a clear propensity of creating confusion in the mind of the public regarding the origin of the goods on which it is used, invoking Section 9(2)(a).
* The court also held that the impugned orders (dated July 25, 2022) were quashed and set aside, and Application numbers 1944698 and 969178 filed by the respondent before the learned Registrar shall stand rejected.
* Appeal CA(COMM.IPD-TM) 158/2022 was allowed with no orders as to costs.

Parties:
- Appellant: Armasuisse
- Respondent: Trade Mark Registry & Anr.

Related PDF source: "26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf"

nodes.title: Page 78
nodes.summary:
The page 78 content is summarized as follows:

The High Court of Delhi deliberates on sections 9(1)(b) and 9(2)(a) regarding the registrability of a trademark in the context of the Armasuisse case (CA 158/2022).

* Section 9(1)(b) considers whether the mark deceives or confuses the consumer, finding it inapplicable to this case.
* The court agrees with Mr. Bakhru that Section 11(3)(a) is not applicable in this instance.
* Observations made about the applicability of Section 9(2)(a) regarding the "SWISS MILITARY" mark apply mutatis mutandis, indicating a propensity for confusion over product origin.
* The court concludes that the marks , and 'SWISS MILITARY' are ineligible for registration in respect of textiles.

Source: PDF source: "26. Armasuisse v. Trade Mark Registry & Anr.pdf" with Neutral Citation Number 2023/DHC/000019 (delivered on January 4, 2023)

Page 78 of 79 
 
 
deceive or confuse the consumer, thereby ruling out the applicability 
of Section 9(1)(b) and 9(2)(a) as well.   
 
161. I agree with Mr. Bakhru, but only in part.  Section 11(3)(a) 
would not apply to the present case.   
 
162. The observations and findings returned by me with respect to 
the applicability of Section 9(2)(a) to the 
 mark, as contained in 
paras 153 to 160 supra, would apply mutatis mutandis to the ‗SWISS 
MILITARY‘ mark impugned in this appeal.  The use of the ‗SWISS 
MILITARY‘ appellation, even by itself and sans any accompanying 
embellishments or emblems, has the clear propensity of creating 
confusion in the mind of the public, regarding the origin of the goods 
on which the mark is used.  The ―confusion factor‖ is the use of the 
appellation ‗SWISS MILITARY‘, and not a black and white cross, 
though the use of the black and white cross may add to the confusion.  
Section 9(2)(a) would, therefore, apply even if the mark ‗SWISS 
MILITARY‘ is used without the accompanying black and white 
cross.    
 
Conclusion 
 
163. Accordingly, the impugned orders dated 25th July 2022 are 
quashed and set aside. It is held that the marks 
, 
  and ‗SWISS 
MILITARY‘ are all ineligible for registration in respect of textiles, as 
claimed by the respondent. Application numbers 1944698 and 969178 
filed by the respondent before the learned Registrar shall stand 
rejected. 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
